text: BR17120 Genetics, Evolution and Diversity: Fungi Jo Hamilton (e-mail: jvh) Objectives and learning outcomes.  Fungi live by absorptive heterotrophy.  Fungi can be – Saprobic – Parasitic – Predatory – Mutualistic.  Major groups differ in their life cycles.  Fungi can be sensitive indicators of environmental change. Major eukaryote lineages diversified in Precambrian A proposed eukaryote phylogeny. Image from http://tolweb.org/Eukaryotes Fungi live by absorbtive heterotrophy  Digest food outside body – Enzymes break down large food molecules – Absorb products through cell membrane – Absorbtive heterotrophy.  Lifestyles: saprobic, parasitic, mutualistic. BorgQueen - Sources clockwise from top left: File:Amanita muscaria tyndrum.jpg, File:Scarlet elf cap cadnant dingle.jpg, File:Mouldy bread alt.jpg, File:Spizellomycete.jpg, File:Aspergillus.jpg, CC BY-SA 2.5, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=7395392 Evolution of fungi  Evolved from unicellular protist with flagellum – Probable common animal ancestor  flagellated protist.  Current evidence – fungi, choanoflagellates & animals share common ancestor not shared by other eukaryotes.  Opisthokonts – flagellum posterior. Evolution of fungi Common protist ancestor Choanoflagellates Animals Fungi Single posterior flagellum (if present) Absorptive heterotrophy Chitin in cell walls Opisthokonts Evolution of fungi  Synapomorphies (shared derived characters) of fungi: – Absorptive hetereotrophy – Chitin in cell walls  Chitin – structural complex polysaccharide.  Fungi – 1 of 4 independent evolutions of large multicellular organisms – (plants, brown algae & animals). Dschanz - own work (drawn with BKchem), Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=2606 282 Unicellular yeasts absorb nutrients directly  Most fungi multicellular.  Unicellular spp. in most groups.  Unicellular free living fungi – Yeasts  Some fungi - yeast & multicellular life cycle stages – Not single taxonomic group.  Yeasts – liquid/moist environs. – Direct nutrient absorbtion - cell surface  Model organisms. Y tambe - Y tambe's file, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php ?curid=233284 Masur - Own work, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php ?curid=1069017 Multicellular fungi use hyphae to absorb nutrients  Body multicellular fungus – Mycelium (plural mycelia).  Mycelium mass tubular filaments – Hyphae (singular hypha) – Nutrient absorbtion.  Hyphae strengthened by chitin. Y_tambe - Y_tambe's file, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=1527577 Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curi d=1021866 Hyphae  Some spp. - septate hyphae – Incomplete septa subdivide hyphae – Controlled movement organelles & nuclei.  Other spp. - undivided multinucleate hyphae – Coenocytic hyphae.  Rhizoids – modified hyphae – Anchor some fungi to substrate – Do not absorb nutrients/water – Not homologous to plant rhizoids. AHiggins12 - Own work - reference image - found here (retrieved May 2012), CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?c urid=19679700 Fungi - intimate contact with environment  Fungal mycelium huge s.a.:volume ratio – Adaptation for absorptive heterotrophy – Lose H2O rapidly – Moist environments.  Some spp. tolerate highly hypertonic environments.  Some spp. tolerate extreme temps. -6OC – 50OC. Tobi Kellner - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=18340817 Saprobic fungi are critical to the carbon cycle  Saprobic fungi – major decomposers – Contribute to decay non-living organic matter – Gain energy, C & N – Recycle elements – Some - decompose fallen trees – Some spp. - enzymes  decompose keratin.  Recycle C releasing it as CO2 – No known fungi fix N. Lebrac - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=34813 31 Diana Marcela Rocabado Reyes, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=522879 8 Parasitic fungi  Facultative parasites – Grow on living organisms or independently.  Obligate parasites – Only grow on living hosts – Specialised nutritional requirements – Plants & insects – common hosts.  Can be non-lethal, pathogenic or lethal. Stu's Images, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid =17599821 Pathogenic fungi  Human pathogens – E.g. althlete’s foot, ringworm – E.g. Pneumocystis spp. – pneumonia – E.g. Candida albicans – oesophagitis. – immunocompromised hosts  Amphibian decline – A chytrid fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) User InvictaHOG on en.wikipedia - Originally from en.wikipedia; description page is (was) here, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid =753151 Peter Daszak, Lee Berger, Andrew A. DOI:10.3201/eid0506.990601., Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid =2327732 Y tambe - Y tambe's file, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php ?curid=233284 Pathogenic fungi  Major plant pathogens – Crop loss – E.g. Puccinia graminis - wheat black stem rust – 1935 epidemic loss ¼ wheat crop in Canada & USA.  Beneficial uses – Fusarium spp. – weed control for certain crops & coca plants (controversial). Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=121493 5 Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=633438 Predatory fungi  Most common strategy secrete sticky substances from hyphae – Hyphae invade trapped prey absorbing nutrients & killing it.  Some spp. soil fungi – 3 cell constricting ring formation – Nematode crawling through ring stimulates fungus – Cells swell & trap worm – Hyphae invade, digest & kill worm. Bob Blaylock - Own work, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=115064 96 Some fungi are mutualistic  Symbiosis – partners in close permanent contact.  Mutualism – both partners benefit.  Lichens – symbiosis – fungus & photosynthetic microorganism – Can survive extreme environments – E.g. Antarctica >100x lichen “spp”. than vascular plants. Jason Hollinger - Mushroom Observer, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid =6051948 Rosser1954 Roger Griffith - Own work, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?cur id=6942802 Lichens  ~20,000 “species”  Assigned name of fungal component – Most are Ascomycota (sac fungi) (plus a basidiomycete yeast?) – Photosynthetic component  often unicellular green alga, cyanobacterium or both.  Variety exposed habitats – Reindeer moss – Cladonia subtenuis – Arctic, sub-Arctic & boreal regions  diet reindeer & other large mammals. CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.ph p?curid=209480 Lichens  Fungi obtain fixed C from algal/cyanobacterial photosynthetic products. – Photosynthetic cells gain favourable environment.  3 major body forms – Crustose (crust-like) – Foliose (leafy) – Fruticose (shrubby). Rosser1954 Roger Griffith - Own work, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/in dex.php?curid=6942802 Jason Hollinger - Mushroom Observer, CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/inde x.php?curid=6051948 Jason Hollinger - Flavoparmelia caperata, CC BY 2.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/inde x.php?curid=50601744 Lichen reproduction  Fragmentation of thallus (vegetative body).  Or soredia (1/few photosynthetic cells bound by fungal hyphae). – Detach, disperse & develop into new thallus.  Sexual reproduction fungal partner – Production & dispersal haploid spores. Ed Uebel - self-made (Photographed by me, Ed Uebel), CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?cur id=2181252 Lichens  Often 1st colonisers of bare rock. – Minerals from air, rain, & dust.  Lichens acidify environment – rock breakdown & soil formation.  As lichen’s dry out photosynthesis ceases – Water content decreases – Insensitive to temperature extremes. Rosser1954 Roger Griffith - Own work, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=694 2802 Mycorrhizae  Many vascular plants depend on symbiosis with fungi – Critical colonisation land by plants.  Mycorrhiza – plant root infected with fungi – Fungus obtains organic compounds (sugars & aas). – Fungus increases plant’s absorbtion H2O & minerals (P). – Fungus provides certain growth hormones & protection against microbial pathogens. CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid =223475 Mycorrhizae  2 types mycorrhizae – Ectomycorrhizae  fungus wraps around root  no penetration of cell walls. – Arbuscular (tree-like) mycorrhizae  enter root & penetrate call walls. Ellen Larsson - R. Henrik Nilsson, Erik Kristiansson, Martin Ryberg, Karl-Henrik Larsson (2005). "Approaching the taxonomic affiliation of unidentified sequences in public databases – an example from the mycorrhizal fungi". BMC Bioinformatics 6: 178. DOI:10.1186/1471-2105-6-178., CC BY 2.5, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=459872 Msturmel - MS Turmel, University of Manitoba, Plant Science Department, Public Domain, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid=755 3044 Mycorrhizal associations are very important  Plants - active arbuscular mycorrhizae - drought resistant.  Healthy forests depend on ectomycorrhizal fungi.  Many crops require inoculation of seeds with mycorrhizal fungi.  Plants without chlorophyll always have mycorrhizae. CC BY-SA 3.0, https://commons.wikimedia.org/w/index.php?curid =223475 Endophytic fungi  Endophytic fungi – Live in above-ground parts of plants without causing deleterious symptoms. – Abundant in plants in all terrestrial environments. – Fungi produce alkaloids  toxic to animals  increase resistance to drought & salt stress. 6 major fungal groups – differ in life cycles Dashed lines indicate probable paraphyly Common ancestor Microsporidia Dikaryon stage Septate hyphae Chytrids Zygospore fungi (Zygomycota) Arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (Glomeromycota) Sac fungi (Ascomycota) Club fungi (Bascidiomycota) Dikarya Gene sequences supports monophyly Plasmogamy precedes karyogamy 6 major fungal groups differ in their life cycles  Self-directed learning on Bb. Fungi and the environment  Lichen diversity & abundance indicate air quality – Cannot excrete absorbed toxins.  Fungi record & remediate environmental pollution – Clean up oil spills & synthetic hydrocarbons.  Reforestation may depend on restoration of mycorrhizal fungi. Summary  Fungi live by absorptive heterotrophy.  Fungi can be – Saprobic – Parasitic – Predatory – Mutualistic.  Major groups differ in their life cycles.  Fungi can be sensitive indicators of environmental change.
